geography.region: Eurasia (China, Persia, Central Asia, Russia, Middle East)

mortality.note: Possibly 10% of world population. Some estimates go higher. Cities like Baghdad, Samarkand, Nishapur completely destroyed. Terror used as deliberate strategy - cities that resisted were annihilated as warning to others.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Organized military campaigns with deliberate terror tactics. Cities given choice: surrender or annihilation.
rationales.profit: Primary driver was tribute, trade route control, and wealth extraction from conquered peoples.
rationales.ideology: Mandate of Heaven concept, but conquest was pragmatic rather than ideologically purifying.
rationales.complicity: Mongol soldiers and administrators directly benefited; conquered peoples often collaborated to survive.

analysis.pattern_note: Terror as military doctrine. Cities that surrendered were spared; those that resisted were annihilated to the last person. Baghdad 1258: 200k-2M killed, libraries burned, irrigation destroyed. Yet Mongols were religiously tolerant and created Pax Mongolica trade network. Shows how extreme violence can coexist with 'civilizational' achievements.
analysis.root_causes: Centralized military power, weak/fragmented opposition, conquest culture
